intro: Coronopus pectinatus, commonly known as the clustered bellflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the Boraginaceae family. It is characterized by its basal rosette of hairy, ovate leaves and produces clusters of bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers. The plant is native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa, often found in rocky or sandy soils. It thrives in full sun and is drought-tolerant, making it suitable for rock gardens. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
